title: Herby Lamb Meatballs
full_text:
Herby Lamb Meatballs
Close
Jump to recipe
Prep
25 mins
Cook
18 mins
Chilling TIme:
30 mins
Total
73 mins
Serves
4
to 6
Cook Mode
(Keep screen awake)
Ingredients
2
slices
white bread
, crust removed and cut into small pieces (about
1
loosely
packed cup
)
3
tablespoons
(
45
ml
)
whole milk
1/2
medium
yellow
onion
(
4
ounces
;
113
g
), grated (about
1/2
cup
)
1
large
egg
1
teaspoon
ground coriander
1/2
teaspoon
ground cumin
1/2
teaspoon
crushed red pepper flakes
1/2
teaspoon
granulated garlic
1/2
cup
loosely packed fresh
mint leaves
(
1/2
ounce
;
14
g
), finely chopped, divided
3/4
cup
, plus
2
tablespoons
(
210
ml
)
whole-milk strained (Greek-style) yogurt
, divided (see notes)
2
tablespoons
(
6
g
)
chopped fresh dill
, divided, plus fronds for garnish
2 1/4
teaspoons
Diamond Crystal kosher salt
, divided; for table salt use half as much by volume
1 1/2
pounds
(
680
g
)
ground lamb
1
tablespoon
(
15
ml
)
extra-virgin olive oil
2
ounces
(
57
g
)
feta cheese
in brine, drained and crumbled (about
1/2

)
1
teaspoon

, plus
1

(from

), plus lemon wedges to serve
Directions
Adjust oven rack to middle position and preheat oven to 400°F (205°C). Line a rimmed baking sheet with parchment paper and set aside. In a large bowl, combine bread with milk and toss to coat. Let stand, stirring occasionally, until bread is completely moist, about 5 minutes. Squeeze bread between your fingers or mash with a spoon to make sure there are no dry spots.
Serious Eats / Jen Causey
Add onion, egg, coriander, cumin, red pepper, garlic, 1/4 cup mint, 2 tablespoons yogurt, 1 tablespoon dill, and 2 teaspoons salt to bread mixture. Using a clean hand or spoon, stir until very well combined. Add ground lamb and, using your hand, continue mixing vigorously, squishing meat and seasonings between your fingers, until just combined and meat has taken on a slightly sticky texture; be careful not to overwork meat.
Using wet hands, roll lamb mixture into 2-ounce (60 g) meatballs (about 16 total). Place on prepared baking sheet, evenly spaced apart, and cover lightly with plastic wrap. Refrigerate meatballs until firm and cold, at least 30 minutes or up to 4 hours.
Serious Eats / Jen Causey
In a 12-inch cast iron, carbon-steel, or stainless-steel skillet, heat oil over medium-high heat until shimmering. Add half of meatballs in an single layer and cook, undisturbed, until browned on 1 side, 1 to 2 minutes. Using tongs, carefully turn meatballs and continue to cook, turning as needed, until browned on all sides, 3 to 4 minutes. Transfer meatballs to a large plate. Repeat with remaining meatballs. Once all meatballs are browned, transfer meatballs back to skillet, and bake until an instant-read thermometer inserted into center of meatballs registers 145°F (63°C), 5 to 7 minutes (see notes).
Serious Eats / Jen Causey
Meanwhile, in a food processor, process feta cheese, lemon zest and juice, remaining 3/4 cup of yogurt, remaining 1/4 cup mint, remaining 1 tablespoon dill, and remaining 1/4 teaspoon salt until mostly smooth, about 2 minutes.
Serious Eats / Jen Causey
Spoon sauce onto a large serving plate or individual plates. Gently set meatballs on top of sauce. Garnish with dill fronds, and serve with lemon wedges.
Serious Eats / Jen Causey
Special Equipment
12-inch cast iron, carbon-steel, or stainless-steel skillet, food processor
Notes
The ideal Greek-style yogurt for this recipe is one that is
completely
strained; many Greek yogurts in the US market are only partially strained. One good option here is Fage, which comes thoroughly strained from the start. If you have another brand that seems slightly thinner, you can place yogurt in a fine-mesh sieve set over a bowl and let stand for about 2 hours. Once the extra water has drained away, you will have a much thicker yogurt to work with.
We think 145°F is an ideal internal temperature for lamb meatballs, but if you have any health concerns such as a compromised immune system among your diners, you can cook them further to 160°F.
Make-Ahead and Storage
The yogurt and feta sauce can be made ahead and refrigerated in an airtight container for up to 4 days.
